A series of nanostructured Ni/SBA-16 catalysts doped with different Ti loadings (0–10 wt%) were prepared and their catalytic behaviors were investigated in the CO2 reforming of methane reaction. Comprehensive physicochemical analyses revealed that a 2 wt% Ti -doping markedly lowered Ni particle size, enlarged specific surface area and mesopore volume, facilitated NiO reduction, intensified metal–support interaction, and enriched surface-active oxygen species, leading to optimal catalytic activity and coke resistance. However, higher Ti loadings (5–10 %) caused degradation of these structural properties compared to the optimal 2 wt% Ti loading, primarily due to the formation of NiTiO3 oxides. Consequently, catalytic performance was significantly reduced. Based on these findings, a synergistic relationship between the active metal (Ni) and tailored surface characteristics was established, which was correlated with the enhanced catalytic activity in the CO2 reforming of methane reaction. The extensive emissions of these harmful gases, primarily CO2 and CH4, have triggered numerous environmental challenges, including glacier melting, rising sea levels, and global temperature escalation[2]. Thermal catalytic reaction of dry reforming of methane (DRM) or CO2 reforming of methane (CRM) can be helpful in mitigating the GHGs emissions in which CO2 and CH4 can be converted concurrently [3]. In this process, syngas (CO and H2) with a desired CO/H2 molar ratio close to 1 can be produced, which is advantageous in the Fischer-Tropsch process for producing valuable chemicals or fuels [4]. Consequently, the CRM reaction can be integrated into the carbon emission reduction system to help achieve a net-zero-carbon and renewable society. Generally, the CRM reaction (Eq. 1) necessitates the participation of an effective catalyst at temperatures exceeding 700 ℃ [3]. However, the high-temperature induced coke deposition and active metal sintering lead to catalyst deactivation, resulting in deactivation of catalyst and reactor blockage [5]. Thus, the catalyst with favorable reactivity and stability have emerged as the research focus. (1) CO2 + CH4 = 2CO + 2H2ΔH298K= 247.3kJ·mol−1 Catalysts based on precious and transition metals have been widely applied in the CRM reaction [3]. Precious metal-based catalysts, such as Rh, Ir, Ru, Pd, Pt, etc., have been proven to exhibit excellent catalytic performance, outstanding coke resistance, and superior anti-sintering properties [6]. Nevertheless, the high cost limits their potential commercialization. Meanwhile, transition metal-based catalysts like Ni, Co, Cu, and Fe have also been developed for catalyzing the CRM reaction [7–10]. Among them, Ni catalysts have attracted intensive interest because of their comparable activity and durability in the CRM reaction compared to precious metals [11]. Although admirable activity and selectivity have been observed for Ni catalysts in the CRM, coke deposition, which mainly originates from methane splitting (CH4 = C + 2 H2, Δ H 298 K 0 = 74.87 KJ/mol) and the Boudouard reaction (2CO = C + CO2, Δ H 298 K 0 = −172 KJ/mol), still remains a main obstacle [12]. Thus, plenty of works have focused on improving the coke and sintering resistance of nickel catalysts. The surface structure such as dispersion of Ni, basic sites, oxygen vacancies and metal-support interaction (MSI), etc. have been studied to mitigate carbon formation[7,13,14]. For instance, numerous studies have shown that an increase in Ni dispersion results in less coke deposition [15]. Luo et al. [16] prepared mesoporous Al2O3 supported nickel catalysts using an alkaline-induced adsorption method, which led to highly dispersed Ni species for the CRM reaction. It was demonstrated that the alkaline treatment caused decomposition, reconstruction, and corrosion of the matrix, thereby facilitating Ni dispersion. Subsequently, this Ni/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a CH4 reforming rate that was twice as high as that of the Ni-Al sample synthesized via the conventional incipient wet impregnation process. Katarzyna et al. [17] synthesized a series of Ni catalysts derived from yttrium-doped double-layered hydroxide materials (hydrotalcite) and applied these materials in the CRM. The results revealed that doping with yttrium could promote an increase in weak and moderate basic sites, better reducibility, and more excellent dispersion of nickel species. Thus, enhanced activity and stability were achieved for such catalysts. In our previous work, the metal-support interaction (MSI) of the Ni-SBA-16 catalyst was optimized by adjusting the preparation process [14]. The CRM tests showed that the sample synthesized by the ammonia evaporation (AE) process exhibited the highest MSI and demonstrated significantly enhanced reaction rates for the reactant molecules in the reforming reaction, which were approximately 1.5 times higher than those of the catalyst synthesized via the wet impregnation (WI) process. Also, the carbon deposition level on the AE method-derived sample after 10 h of time-on-stream (TOS) was only half of that on the WI-derived sample. Increasing Ni dispersion and enhancing MSI have been proved to effectively enhance the stability of Ni catalysts. Besides, some new preparation technologies have been developed to promote Ni dispersion [18]. For example, the atomic layer deposition (ALD) method has been employed for the preparation of Ni catalysts [18–21]. It has been found that the deposition of thin alumina overcoats on Ni catalysts by the ALD method can effectively suppress Ni sintering and coke formation in the CRM process [21]. It appears that Al overcoating is an effective approach to promote Ni dispersion. Stair et al. [18] synthesized Ni/Al2O3@La2O3 catalyst by combining La2O3 doping with Al2O3 and La2O3 overcoating using the ALD method. It was reported that doping La2O3 could suppress the initial low activity of the ALD-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst during CRM operation by controlling the formation of NiAl2O4 species, which are responsible for the initial low activity of Ni catalysts. Moreover, the Al2O3 coating layer on the La2O3-doped Ni/Al2O3 catalyst contributed to enhanced stability. As mentioned above, surface structure have significant effects on the catalytic behaviors of Ni catalysts during CRM. In light of this, tailoring the surface structure of Ni catalyst is an efficient strategy for achieving coke resistance and anti-sintering performance of Ni catalysts. A variety of methods, such as doping with promoters [22–24], adjusting the preparation process [25,26], constructing core-shell structures [27,28], synthesizing atomically dispersed catalysts [29], modifying supports [30], and redesigning reactor systems [31] etc., have been developed to tailor Ni catalysts. Doping promoters have been widely adopted as a catalyst modification method due to its simplicity and efficiency [32–36]. For instance, Tada et al. [37] doped the Ni/SBA-16 catalyst with ceria for CRM. The results revealed that cerium doping could effectively enhance the reducibility of active metals, induce a stronger Ni-ceria interaction, and generate abundant Ce3+ species, all of which contributed to improved reaction conversion rates and enhanced durability of the cerium-doped catalyst in the CRM process. Kawi and his/her collaborators [38] synthesized an SBA-15-supppoted nickel catalyst via the AE process and modified it with magnesium (Mg). The characterization techniques revealed that the AE method facilitated the formation of phyllosilicate structures during the synthesis, thereby enhancing the metal-support interaction (MSI) and increasing the hydroxyl group density. Additionally, doping Mg could promote the generation of moderate basic sites on the Ni catalyst. Besides, promoters such as Mg, La, Si, Y, Mo, etc., have also been widely investigated in the CRM process [18,35,39–41]. In our previous study, we demonstrated that mesoporous silica SBA - 16 is a promising matrix for Ni catalyst in the CRM process [14]. Although superior CRM activity has been achieved on Ni/SBA-16 catalyst, it is still essential to improve this catalyst toward reduced carbon deposition and enchanced long-term stability. Thus, we aim to engineer the structure of Ni/SBA-16 through strategic doping of promoters to further enhance its catalytic activity and resistance to coking. CeO2 and ZrO2 have been extensively studied as promoters or supports for Ni catalysts due to their exceptional oxygen storage and release capability [33,42–46]. Such capability can effectively activate CO2 molecules in the CRM mechanism. Compared to CeO2 and ZrO2, TiO2 has received less attentions in Ni catalyst modification for CRM process [44,47–49]. It has been proven that ceria is an appropriate promoter for Ni/SBA-16 nanoparticles [50]. Meanwhile, CeO2/TiO2 mixed oxides have been shown to serve as a superior support for Ni catalyst in the CRM process [44]. TiO2-supported catalysts with different crystalline phases have been found to significantly influence catalytic activity [51]. DFT studies on TiO2 revealed that the (0 0 1) surface exhibits excellent coke resistance [52]. Titanium as a promoter has also been reported to enhance the performance of Ni catalysts [53]. To date, limited research has been conducted on Ti-modified mesoporous material-based Ni catalysts. In this context, Ti-doped nickel catalysts supported on the SBA-16 matrix were synthesized in this study to investigate the role of surface structure engineering through TiO2 modification. Additionally, this work aims to establish a foundation for future studies on surface structures of mixed oxide systems (Si, Ce, Zr, Y, and Ti) for CRM applications. This study aims to clarify the effects of Ti-doping on the textural, structural, and chemical properties of Ni catalysts to uncover the synergy between active metals and the support. Furthermore, the impact of this synergy on CRM performance and resistance to carbon deposition in nickel catalysts was systematically analyzed. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Material and catalyst syntheses The three-dimensional material SBA-16 with mesopores was synthesized using a modified method as previously reported [54]. In detail, Pluronic F127 copolymer (EO106PO70EO106, BASF, 3 g) was transferred to a Teflon bottle followed by the addition of deionized water (144 g, produced in the lab). After stirring thoroughly, a measured amount of concentrated hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37 wt%, 5.94 g, Sigma Aldrich) was added dropwise to the solution and mixed magnetically. Butanol-1 (9 g, Sigma Aldrich) was then added to the mixture after 0.5 h of magnetic stirring. Subsequently, the mixture was magnetically stirred at 40 °C for 1.0 h to ensure complete homogenization. The molar ratio of butanol-1 to Pluronic F127 was maintained at 3:1. Next, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 14.2 g, Sigma Aldrich) was added dropwise as the silica source. Following these steps, the Teflon bottle was maintained at 40 °C for 24 h under continuous stirring. Then, the bottle was transferred to an oven set at 80 ℃ for 48 h to initiate hydrothermal synthesis. After the hydrothermal process, the temperature of the container was reduced to approximately 30 °C. Finally, the solid was filtered and washed with distilled water and ethanol to obtain a white precipitate, which was subsequently dried in an oven at 110 °C overnight. Finally, the resulting solid was ground and then calcined at 550 °C for 5.0 h with a temperature ramp of 5 °C per minute to obtain the desired mesoporous material. The nanostructured catalyst was synthesized using a nitric acid-assisted ultrasonic impregnation process. Typically, nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2∙6 H2O, 99 %, Sigma-Aldrich) was dissolved in multiple beakers, followed by the adding of titanium(IV) isopropoxide (Titanium n-propanol, Ti(OC3H7)4, purity > 98 %, Sigma-Aldrich) at varying Ti loadings (0, 2, 5, 10 wt%), respectively. After thorough mixing, 1 g of the synthesized SBA-16 material was added to each corresponding salt solution. Subsequently, the mixtures were subjected to ultrasonic treatment for 30 min. Then, the containers were left to stand for 24 h to complete the impregnation process. Next, the samples were dried in an oven at 110 °C overnight. Finally, the dried solids were ground and calcined in an electrical furnace at 550 °C for 5 h with a heating rate of 5 °C per minute. All catalysts contained 10 wt% Ni, and the Ti loadings were 2, 5, and 10 wt%, respectively. Therefore, the unmodified and Ti-modified catalysts were denoted as Ni/SBA-16 and Ni-xTi/SBA-16 (x = 2, 5, 10 wt%), respectively. 2.2 Characterization of the materials The nitrogen (N2) adsorption-desorption technique (Micromeritics ASAP 2020) was applied for the analysis of the materials’ texture. The obtained isotherms and the pore size distribution profiles were presented in Fig. 1 a and Fig. 1 b, respectively. The values of SSA, Vp and rp were listed in Table 1. As displayed in Fig. 1 a, similar type four isotherms with H1 hysteresis loops were obtained all for Ti-doped and Ti-free samples, indicating that a mesoporous structure with relatively uniform cylindrical pores was successfully synthesized [56]. As shown in Table 1, the doping of Ti at 2 wt% results in a significant increase in SSA. With a further increase in Ti loading to 5–10 wt%, the SSA of catalysts decrease compared to that of 2 wt% Ti-doped catalyst. Meanwhile, there are no distinct changes on the Vp of all samples. Regarding rp (as shown in Fig. 1 b and Table 1), Ti doping results in a slight reduction in pore size, likely due to the accumulation and subsequent blockage of oxides within the pores during synthesis process. Therefore, it is concluded that Ti doping enhances the SSA and Vp of the Ni catalyst. Only a mild decline in rp was monitored for the Ti-doped samples. Concurrently, the sample doped with 2 wt% Ti exhibits the highest SSA and Vp. The XRD profiles had been obtained for detecting the structural properties of the calcined materials. As depicted in Fig. 2 a, the diffraction peaks at 2θ value of 37.2, 43.3, 62.9, 75.4 and 79.4 ° were attributed to the NiO lattice plane (PDF#44–1159) corresponding to the (1 0 1), (0 1 2), (1 0 4), (1 1 3) and (2 0 2) reflections, respectively. The broad signal without sharp peaks at the 2θ range of around 15–25 ° was attributed to the diffraction originating from short-range ordered structure inside amorphous silica as demonstrated in other publication [57]. Only crystalline NiO was detected in the Ni/SBA-16 sample. Meanwhile, the NiO peaks broaden with Ti loading rising from 2 to 5 wt%, indicating that possible formation of NiO crystallites with decreased size on the Ti-doped catalysts. Furthermore, no TiO2 diffraction peaks were detected at low Ti loadings (2–5 wt%), suggesting that TiO2 was evenly distributed on the surface of mesoporous matrix. When Ti loading comes at 10 wt%, nearly no clear diffraction peaks of NiO were detected, suggesting that Ti enhanced Ni dispersion significantly. Additionally, diffraction peaks of titanium oxides were detected on the 10 wt% Ti-doped sample, as shown in Fig. 2 b. The peaks at 2θ values of 24.1, 33.1, 35.7, 40.9, 49.5, 54.1, 62.5, and 64.2 ° were assigned to nickel titanium oxide (NiTiO3, PDF card number #33–0960), indicating the production of alloy or solid solution for nickel and titanium oxides. Concurrently, the peak at 2θ value of 25.3 was attribute to TiO2 species in the anatase (PDF card number #21–1272) or brookite (PDF card number #29–1360) forms. In summary, a mixture of nickel titanate and titanium oxide grains was formed in the 10 wt% Ti-doped sample. The XRD experiments were also carried out on reduced samples. In Fig.S2, it can be seen that there are clear diffraction peaks located at 2θ of 44.6, 52.0, and 76.5°, which can be assigned to the presence of Ni metal [58]. After reduction, only peaks of Ni metal and broad peaks of SiO2 are detected over samples with low loading of Ti (<10 wt%). Nearly no peaks TiO2 and NiTiO3 are detected, demonstrating highly dispersed Ti species over samples with low Ti loading. of When Ti loading comes to 10 wt%, TiO2 and NiTiO3 are also found. This indicates that high loading of Ti leads to less reducible nickel species and larger particles of Ti species. The crystal diameters of NiO, Ni metal and NiTiO3 calculated by Eq.(2) were listed in Table 1. One thing could be confirmed that the NiO grain diameter decreases sharply as the increasing content of Ti. Meanwhile, large crystal of NiTiO3 (19.6 nm) is formed over 10 wt% Ti-doped sample. After reduction, the redistribution of Ni species happened [58]. But, Ti-doped samples still shows smaller crystal size of Ni metal compared to undoped sample. Based on the results above, one trend can be concluded from Table 1 that NiO crystal size decreases with the increase of Ti loading. This could be attributed to the lattice change as the incorporation of Ti4+ into NiO lattice. As the difference between the ionic radius of Ti4+ and Ni2+, the local stress fields in the NiO lattice were formed, which hindered the growth of NiO grains [59,60]. Meanwhile, the heterojunction such as NiTiO3 formed at the interface of TiO2 and NiO also helps to hinder the growth of NiO crystal[61–63]. In conclusion, Ti doping could promote the increase of Ni dispersion. 3.1.2 Surface chemical states and binding energies on reduced materials For purpose of determining the surface chemical states of the materials, the XPS characterizations were also carried out on reduced samples (800℃). As depicted in Fig. 3 and Fig.S1, XPS spectra of Ni2p, Si2p, O1s and Ti2p were collected. The binding energies of Ni2p3/2 on catalysts and the references (Ni2+ and Ni0), and the Ti2p3/2 on catalysts as well as the atomic ratios on the surface of catalysts were summarized in Table 2. From Fig.S1a and Table 2, it was shown that there were considerable adifferences between the Ni2p binding energies of catalysts and those of references, which might be caused by the different instruments and oxidation during sample transfer. For catalysts, the Ni2p peak moved towards lower binding energy with increasing Ti loading. Meanwhile the Ti2p peak (Fig. 3 b and Table 2 ) also shifted towards higher binding energies as increased Ti content. This can be assigned to the Ni incorporation into the TiO2 lattice, which was also evidenced by the formation of NiTiO3 in XRD. Moreover, the Ni incorporation into TiO2 lattice may also induce defects in TiO2, which may contribute to the partial reduction of Ti4+ to Tiδ+ with lower valence under high reduction temperature (800℃), thus creating oxygen vacancies [64]. Meanwhile, as increasing content of Ti, the Si2p signal intensity decreased, which was designated to the Ti deposition on the matrix’s external surface. Moreover, a shift of Si2p towards lower binding energy was also found, which could be caused by the Ti incorporation into silica structure. Similar results were also found in other publication [53]. From Fig. 3 a, the O1s spectra were fitted to three spectra positioned at binding energy of 533.7, 532.4 and 529.7 eV, respectively, indicating the presence of surface hydroxyl oxygen (OOH), lattice oxygen (OL) and lattice oxygen inside metal oxide (OM) [46]. From Table 2, distinct discrepancies of the atomic ratios regarding Ni and Ti were registered on Ti-doped samples, indicating great changes of surface species due to Ti modification. Specifically, 2 wt%Ti loading promoted the dispersions of metallic Ni and Ti species on the surface of the support while 5–10 wt%Ti loading led to possible surface accumulation. As for surface oxygen species, the Ti-doping could promote the increase of surface hydroxyl species, with the 2% Ti-doped sample exhibiting the highest content of OOH. These surface hydroxyl species can be assigned to the oxygen species on support and oxygen vacancies from titanium species [63]. 2 wt% Ti-doping resulted in the highest distributions of nickel plus titanium species on the tested samples. Thus, the highest content of surface hydroxyl species was obtained on 2 wt% Ti-doped sample. 3.1.3 Reducibility properties of materials from TPR-H2 For the sake of evaluating the reducibility properties of calcined samples, the H2 temperature-programmed reduction measurement (H2-TPR) had been carried out on calcined materials. Also, the H2 consumption was calculated in Table 3. As displayed in Fig. 4, the reduction curves of samples could be fitted into 3 main peaks i.e., α, β and γ. The α peak positioned around 270 ℃ could be assigned to the reduction of surface adsorbed oxygen species [46,53]. While the β and γ peaks of Ti-free sample indicated the reducible nickel oxide with different MSI. However, the β and γ peaks could not be fully excluded the partial reduction of NiTiO3 and mixed oxides of NiO and TiO2 on Ti-doped samples[65]. As the increased Ti loading, the reducibility behaviors of catalysts doped with Ti change significantly. The β and γ reduction peaks shifted towards higher temperature, indicating stronger MSI formed as the Ti doping. Furthermore, the H2 consumption (Table 3) values of α and β peaks were all larger on Ti doped samples with the consumption of γ peak compared to undoped sample. Meanwhile, the highest total H2 consumption was registered on 2 wt% Ti-doped sample, however, the total H2 consumption value decreased when Ti loading exceeded 2 wt%. This indicates that the low content (2 wt%) of Ti doping leads to higher reducibility of nickel species, resulting to better catalytic performance in CRM process [26]. Besides, the peak shifts towards higher temperature of β and γ on Ti-doped samples (2–5 wt%) also indicates enhanced Ni-support interaction. In a word, low content (2 wt%) of Ti doping has positive effects on promoting the reduction of NiO and enhancing Ni-support interaction. However, higher loading of Ti-doping leads to the loss of reducibility owing to the formation of NiTiO3 solid solution, thus results in less active Ni sites. 3.1.4 Basicity measurement of catalysts In order to gain the basic sites distribution of the materials. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) experiments were carried out on reduced catalysts. The desorption curves were depicted in Fig. 5 . Generally, the basicity of Ni catalyst mostly comes from the properties of support according to reports [17,66]. Based on the desorption temperature of CO2, the basic sites distribution was depicted in Fig. 5 and the number of basic sites was calculated in Table 4. As depicted in Fig. 5, the desorption curves of catalysts could be fitted to three types of peak based on desorption temperature, i.e., weak (<200 ℃), medium (200–300 ℃) and strong basic sites (>400 ℃) [67,68]. It can be seen that the basic sites of Ti-doped catalysts have a transformation from strong into weak or moderate basic sites compared to Ti-free catalyst. This indicates that the Ti doping promotes the increase of weak plus medium basic sites at the cost of strong basic sites. Notably, compared to the undoped sample, two peaks corresponding to strong basic sites on Ti-doped samples were observed. This may be attributed to the presence of new species e.g., NiTiO3 and interfaces between NiO and TiO2 as confirmed by XRD and XPS, which have different CO2 adsorption properties. As listed in Tables 4, 2% Ti-doped catalyst has the highest amount of weak and moderate basicity. Plenty of research works demonstrated that the weak plus moderate basicity were active sites for adsorbing CO2 molecules. In contrast, strong basicity had limited adsorption capability towards CO2 [67,68]. In conclusion, the low loading of Ti-doping (2 %) would promote the increases of weak plus moderate basic sites of catalyst, which could facilitate the CRM activity. 3.2 CRM activity test of catalysts The reduction temperature was set to 800℃ based on the TPR results in order to reduce the catalyst thoroughly. At first, the catalysts were tested at 800℃ for CRM, but there were no great differences of the activity test results. All catalysts had showed high values of the CO2 conversion and CH4 conversion more than 90 %. Thus, the catalytic performance tests were carried out at 700 ℃ in order to study the activity differences. The CO2 conversion, CH4 conversion, reaction rates of reactants as well as H2/CO molar ratio were displayed in Fig. 6 a, b, c, d and e, respectively. It can be seen that the 2 wt% of Ti-doped sample has the highest conversion values while the samples with higher loading of Ti (5–10 wt%) doesn’t exhibit large differences compared to Ti-free sample. Meanwhile, the reaction rates (the molar amount of reactants converted per unit mass of catalyst per unit of time) also have similar trends. Furthermore, the Ti-doped samples all show better stabilities compared to the undoped sample, which the conversions and reaction rates of reactants begin to decrease after 300 min. At the same time, the H2/CO ratios of catalysts show no significant differences. In summary, the 2 % of Ti-doped sample shows the best CRM activity and stability. In Table S1, Ni catalysts improved by different additives were summarized and compared with the Ti-doped Ni catalysts in this study. As can be seen from Table S1, additives such as Mg, Y, Ce, Zr, Mn, Mo, La, and barium etc., have positive effects on the performance of Ni catalysts in the CRM reaction. The promotional effects of Ti on Ni catalysts had also been confirmed by other reports [69]. However, an opposite result was observed in this study, where appropriate Ti-doping had a relatively high positive effect on the performance of the Ni catalyst. Meanwhile, the 2 %Ti-doped Ni/SBA-16 catalyst exhibited a comparative activity (CO2 conversion: 72 %, CH4 conversion: 62 %) at 700 ℃ and a very high WHSV of 135,000 mL∙gcat −1∙h−1. Such good activity could be attributed to the structural changes arising from Ti doping. Turnover frequencies (TOF) of Ti-doped with the best performance and undoped sample were displayed on Fig. 7. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the TOF value of CO2 (Average: 8.6 S−1) for Ti-doped sample doesn’t show significant difference compared to the undoped one. While in Fig. 6 a, the Ti-doped sample showed much higher CO2 conversion compared to Ti-free sample. Generally, the TOF value is structure sensitive, which could be related to plenty of structure factors, including density and uniformity of active sites, surface electronic structure, crystal plane orientation, pore structure, metal-support interaction, and surface defect [70]. In XPS, TPR-H2, and TPD-CO2 results, it had been demonstrated that doping Ti promoted the increase of surface adsorbed oxygen species on the Ti-doped catalysts, which could be attributed to the increased oxygen vacancies and surface hydroxyl species from TiO2. These surface defects would promote the increase of TOF value. In XRD part, Ti-doping promotes the decrease of NiO crystal size, which would also contribute to higher TOF in CRM. As reported anywhere, the mechanism of CRM reforming reaction on Ni catalysts was involved in the adsorption and dissociation of CH4 and CO2 molecules on Ni atoms and support, respectively. Generally, the CO2 molecules adsorb on the surface of support to form carbonate intermediates (e.g., CO3 2-), then decompose into CO* and surface oxygen (O*), finally form the CO [71]. As for CH4, after the adsorption of CH4 on the Ni surface, it gradually dehydrogenates to form H*, CH3*, CH2*, CH*, and C* species, then the dissociated H* would form H2 [13,71]. Meanwhile, C* may further combine with surface oxygen to produce CO or form coke [13]. Thus, oxygen vacancies or deficit sites and Ni dispersion are super vital for CRM. Besides, the synergistic effect between support and nickel sites was also significantly important for TOF since that support could affect the activity of metals through electron transfer or geometric constraints [70]. Although the surface defects contribute to higher TOF, too strong MSI may cause TOF loss. Higher MSI and more surface defects were observed on 2 wt%Ti-doped sample, these factors could jointly lead to a similar TOF value of CO2 on 2 wt%Ti-doped sample as compared to the undoped sample. The TOF value (Average: 7.2 S−1) of CH4 for Ti-doped sample is higher than that of undoped sample during the test period, which could be attributed to the structural tuning derived from Ti-doping as discussed above. The higher Ni dispersion was confirmed on 2 wt%Ti-doped sample. Higher Ni dispersion leads to better CH4 conversion rate since CH4 mostly decomposes on Ni active sites. In conclusion, Ti-doping could change the electronic properties, Ni dispersion, surface oxygen vacancies of Ni catalysts, all of these modifications contribute to better activity plus durability on the Ti-doped Ni catalyst. 3.3 Characterization on spent catalysts 3.3.1 Morphology of catalysts after CRM reaction from TEM/HRTEM The morphology insights and particle size distribution of the samples after test were characterized using HR/TEM techniques. The areas referring to particle size distribution and enlargement were labelled in the figures. As illustrated in Fig. 8, an ordered cubic structure was detected for both tested catalysts, suggesting that the cubic mesoporous structure was maintained in all samples [54]. The Ni particle size distribution was also measured for the samples as shown in Table S2. Following the CRM reaction, numerous large Ni particles had formed on the Ti-free sample. In comparison to the Ti-free sample, which exhibited a mean grain size of 21.1 nm (Table S2), the Ti-doped sample exhibited a significantly smaller particle size, with a mean grain size of 10.7 nm (Table S2), confirming that Ti-doping enhanced the distribution of nickel species on the surface of sample, in line with the findings in XRD. Additionally, carbon nanotubes were observed on both Ti-free and Ti-doped catalysts, indicative of coke production during the reaction process. Moreover, it was found that coke particles were more readily produced on the larger nickel particles of the undoped catalyst, as shown in Fig. 8 a. A similar finding, corroborated by other researchers, indicates that coke formation was suppressed on smaller Ni particles [72]. In comparison to the Ti-free sample, fewer carbon nanotubes formed on the Ti-doped sample, suggesting enhanced coke resistance. This finding can be assigned to the smaller nickel particles on the Ti-modified sample. Meanwhile, the HRTEM was also carried out on the samples after reaction. As depicted in Fig. 9, the lattice fringes corresponding to metallic nickel were detected on all samples. Meanwhile, the TiO2 particle was detected near to the Ni particle, which means more Ni-Ti interfaces existed on Ti-doped sample. 3.3.2 TGA test of catalysts after CRM Thermogravimetry analysis (TGA) was performed on catalysts after CRM test for analyzing the carbon formation during CRM process. The weight loss curves versus temperature had been depicted on Fig. 10. In Fig. 10, all samples experienced an initial weight decrease at the beginning of heating process (<200 ℃), which was assigned to the evaporation of adsorbed H2O impurities [14]. At temperature range of 200–530 ℃, a slight increase trend was monitored on all catalysts, indicating the oxidation of nickel metal particles. After 600 ℃, the sharp decrease of weight was described to the oxidation of coke into CO2 [14,16]. After 700 ℃, the weight decrease trends of all samples began to stop and the curves tend to stabilize. From TGA, it can be concluded that low loading of Ti (2–5 %) can suppress the coke formation compared to the undoped sample while high loading of Ti (10 %) would lead to more coke formation. This may be assigned to the formation of NiTiO3. As discussed in XRD, higher Ti loading promote the formation of NiTiO3 with larger crystal size. Too much NiTiO3 resulted in the decreases of Ni and Ti distribution, NiO reducibility and surface oxygen species, which led to more coke formation [14]. Although the best catalytic performance was obtained on 2 wt%Ti-doped sample, larger NiO crystal size (12.6 nm, Table 1) weakened its anti-coke performance. As for 5 wt%Ti-doped sample, very small NiO crystals (4.8 nm) and rare NiTiO3 crystals (not determined by XRD) jointly contribute to the lowest carbon deposition. The positive effect of Ti promoter was widely demonstrated on various catalysts for CRM reaction[44,49,53]. Herein, it’s not a surprise that doping Ti has a positive effect on Ni-Ti-SBA-16 catalysts in CRM. Interestingly, only the 2 %Ti-doped catalyst showed the improved activity. The XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption and TEM findings demonstrated that the Ti-doping with low loading can promote the dispersion of Ni. It was well known that higher Ni dispersion would contribute to better CRM activity and stability [68]. Nonetheless, the CRM activity test (Fig. 8) shows that only 2 % Ti-doped catalyst performs significant increase of activity. This phenomenon indicates that the CRM activity and stability are not only depends on the state of metallic nickel but also up to the structural properties of the matrix or interface. Wang et al. [13] revealed the synergy between Ni metal and oxygen vacancies derived from ZrO2 to promote the stability of ZrO2-supported Ni catalyst in CRM reaction. It was confirmed that such produced carbon from CH4 decomposition on Ni metal could react with the contiguous active oxygen species or lattice oxygen inside zirconium dioxide to produce carbon monoxide and oxygen vacancies. While such produced oxygen vacancies near Ni metal can facilitate the activation of CO2. As shown in Fig. 11, a synergy between Ni metal and surface oxygen species as well as basicity was built in which the 2 %Ti-doped catalyst had the best improvement of surface property. In the HRTEM part of this work, the TiO2 particles nearby Ni metal were registered. Also, the increases of weak plus moderate basic sites over 2 %Ti-doped sample were proved. Meanwhile, the 2 %Ti doped sample also performs the highest number of surface oxygen species as revealed in XPS part. Thus, a synergy between Ni metal and surface oxygen species may be established on Ni-2Ti/SBA-16 catalyst for CRM. The increase of Ni dispersion brings more surface-active nickel sites for the activation and dissociation of CH4 molecules while oxygen species or vacancies derived from TiO2 bring more active sites to activate CO2 molecules. By this way, the CRM activity of 2 wt%Ti-modified catalyst was intensified. In TGA part, it was found that low loading of Ti (2–5 %) also contributed to stronger carbon resistance on Ti-doped samples. The anti-coke property may also thank to the influence of surface oxygen species derived from Ti species. Han et al. [24] did a detailed research on the influence of surface oxygen species on the activity and durability of ZrO2-supported sample doped by rare earth metals for CRM reaction. Their works found that the active oxygen species on the surface of the support were significantly helpful to the activation and dissociation of CO2 and CH4 molecules. Meanwhile, the surface oxygen species also facilitate the elimination of carbon by promoting CO2 activation to produce active O* species at high temperature. So, a carbon removal mechanism may also be established in which the surface oxygen species promote the CO2 activating and thus facilitate the elimination of coke. At the same time, the formation of anatase as confirmed by HRTEM has been confirmed to have a positive role in the coke elimination. Neyts et al. [52] studied carbon resistance of anatase phase of titanium dioxide by density functional theory (DFT) method. Their research revealed that formed CHx species from CH4 dissociation on the surface of anatase catalyst tended to hydrogenation instead of dehydrogenation at the investigation temperature range. Also, the durability of C and CH species were much lower compared to those of CH2 and CH3 species. Thus, high coke resistance was obtained on anatase catalyst. Back to this research, the TiO2 anatase near to Ni metals was also beneficial to the stronger coke resistance. However, the CRM activity plus carbon resistance on Ti-doped samples with high loading (5–10 %) decreased sharply compared to those of 2 %Ti-doped sample. This can be assigned to the decrease of reducible of nickel sites as illustrated in H2-TPR part, which resulted in less Ni active sites. The XRD results indicate that high lowing of Ti-doping also promotes the formation of NiTiO3 solid solution, which higher temperature is needed for its reduction. N2 adsorption-desorption characterization also reveals losses of textural properties due to high Ti loading. The study from Castaño et al. [73] found that too much TiOx overlayers on Ni/TiO2 catalyst would result in the loss of accessibility of nickel sites to reactants, thus, led to worse activity and stability. Meanwhile, incomplete coverage of TiOx overlayer on Ni metal contributed to better activity and coke resistance. Herein, high loading of Ti over Ti-doped samples results in decreases towards activity and coke resistance. In a word, the CRM activity plus durability of Ni catalysts depends on the synergy between nickel sites and surface structure (active basic sites, oxygen vacancies, surface oxygen species, stronger metal-support interaction). Low loading of Ti-doping not only ameliorate the Ni dispersion but also facilitate the improvement of surface structure. Thus, the highest CRM activity plus coke resistance had been achieved over 2 %Ti-doped sample. Nonetheless, high loading of Ti led to worse textural properties, decrease of reducible NiO, less surface oxygen species and basic sites, which resulted in the decreases of activity plus carbon resistance. In conclusion, the low loading (2 %) of Ti could facilitate the dispersion of nickel species, the formation of Ni-Ti interface, more reducible NiO, more surface oxygen species and active basicity on Ti-doped catalyst, herein, a better activity and coke resistance was realized on 2 %Ti-doped sample. The synergy between Ni metals and surface structural properties jointly contributed to the improvement of Ni-baded catalyst in CRM reaction. 4 Conclusion The surface structure of the Ni nanostructured catalyst supported on SBA-16 was tuned by Ti-doping. The characterization results revealed that a low loading (2 %) of Ti could promote the increases of specific surface area, pore volume, Ni dispersion, NiO reducibility, basic sites, surface oxygen species, and a stronger Ni-Ti interaction. However, higher loadings of Ti (5–10 %) led to the loss of such structural properties. The CRM activity and stability tests indicated that the 2 % Ti-doped catalyst exhibited the highest CRM activity and durability, while higher loadings of Ti (5–10 %) showed no significant improvement in CRM activity compared to the unmodified catalyst. Moreover, the best coke resistance performance was obtained with the 2 % Ti-doped catalyst, which was attributed to the joint contributions of better Ni dispersion, surface oxygen species, and anatase TiO2. This study confirms the synergy between Ni metals and surface structural properties corresponding to the promoted CRM activity and coke resistance of Ni catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A series of nanostructured Ni/SBA-16 catalysts doped with different Ti loadings (0–10 wt%) were prepared and their catalytic behaviors were investigated in the CO2 reforming of methane reaction. Comprehensive physicochemical analyses revealed that a 2 wt% Ti -doping markedly lowered Ni particle size, enlarged specific surface area and mesopore volume, facilitated NiO reduction, intensified metal–support interaction, and enriched surface-active oxygen species, leading to optimal catalytic activity and coke resistance. However, higher Ti loadings (5–10 %) caused degradation of these structural properties compared to the optimal 2 wt% Ti loading, primarily due to the formation of NiTiO3 oxides. Consequently, catalytic performance was significantly reduced. Based on these findings, a synergistic relationship between the active metal (Ni) and tailored surface characteristics was established, which was correlated with the enhanced catalytic activity in the CO2 reforming of methane reaction.
